skill.name: documentation-writer
skill.description: Expert technical writer for Logseq Template Graph project. Generates comprehensive, accurate, and well-structured documentation for modules, features, guides, and APIs. Activates when asked to "write docs", "document this", "create README", "update documentation", or similar requests. Analyzes code/templates to extract information and writes clear, user-focused documentation following project style.

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill with no code execution. Static scanner produced 98 false positives by misidentifying markdown documentation syntax as executable code. No network access, no cryptographic operations, no external commands. Previous audit confirmed safe.

content.value_statement: Developers spend hours creating documentation that quickly becomes outdated. This skill analyzes source code and templates to generate accurate, well-structured module READMEs, user guides, and API documentation automatically. It validates all commands and examples before documenting.
actual_capabilities: Generate comprehensive module READMEs from source code analysis
Create step-by-step user guides with tested instructions
Write API documentation for scripts and command-line tools
Extract class and property information from EDN templates
Validate all code examples before including in documentation
Follow Schema.org mapping conventions for structured data
limitations: Designed specifically for Logseq Template Graph project structure
Cannot document codebases without source files to analyze
Does not test functionality on systems without required tools installed

use_cases.title: Document new modules
use_cases.description: Generate READMEs for new modules by analyzing classes, properties, and relationships in source EDN files.

use_cases.title: Create user guides
use_cases.description: Write step-by-step guides for features, installation, and workflows with tested commands and examples.

use_cases.title: Document scripts and CLIs
use_cases.description: Create reference documentation for build scripts, export tools, and command-line interfaces with complete examples.

prompt_templates.title: Document new module
prompt_templates.scenario: Create documentation for a new module
prompt_templates.prompt: Document the [module-name] module. Read the source files in source/[module-name]/ and generate a comprehensive README with classes, properties, usage examples, and Schema.org references.

prompt_templates.title: Update installation guide
prompt_templates.prompt: Update docs/user-guide/installation.md with new steps for [tool or feature]. Read the existing guide and add accurate, tested installation instructions.

prompt_templates.title: Write API docs
prompt_templates.prompt: Document scripts/[script-name]. Analyze the code and create an API reference with parameters, options, examples, exit codes, and usage scenarios.

prompt_templates.title: Create feature guide
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a user guide for the [feature-name] feature. Include what it does, when to use it, step-by-step instructions, examples, and troubleshooting tips.

output:
# Person Module

The Person module provides classes for tracking individuals including personal information, professional details, and relationships.

## Classes

**Person** - Represents a human being
- Parent: Thing
- Properties: 36 properties
- Use for: Tracking contacts, team members, and individuals

**Patient** - Person receiving medical care
- Parent: Person
- Properties: Medical-related properties

## Properties

**email** (URL, :one) - Email address
- Used by: Person, Organization
- Example: "user@example.com"

**jobTitle** (Text, :one) - Job title
- Used by: Person
- Example: "Senior Engineer"

# Build Script API

## bb scripts/build.clj

**Purpose**: Compile templates and generate output files

**Usage**: `bb build [options]`

**Options**:
| Option | Description | Default |
|--------|-------------|---------|
| --target | Output format | "html" |
| --verbose | Show detailed output | false |

**Exit Codes**:
- 0: Success
- 1: Build error
- 2: Invalid arguments

**Examples**:
```bash
# Build with default settings
bb build

# Build HTML output
bb build --target html
```

best_practices: Test all commands and code examples before including them in documentation
Use concrete, real-world examples instead of generic placeholders
Cross-reference related documentation and keep links current
anti_patterns: Using placeholders instead of tested, working examples
Leaving outdated information in documentation without updates
Assuming readers have expert-level knowledge without explanations

faq.question: What types of documentation can this skill create?
faq.answer: Module READMEs, user guides, technical references, API documentation for scripts and commands, and feature documentation.

faq.question: What file formats does this skill support?
faq.answer:: EDN format for Logseq templates, Markdown for documentation files, and Clojure for build scripts.

faq.question: Can this skill work with any programming project?
faq.answer: It works best with Logseq Template Graph. For other projects, it can read source files but may not follow optimal structure.

faq.question: Does this skill store or transmit my data?
faq.answer: No. This is a prompt-based skill that generates documentation using standard Claude Code tools locally.

faq.question: What tools does this skill use?
faq.answer: Read, Write, Edit, Grep, Glob, and Bash tools to analyze files and validate documentation accuracy.

faq.question: How is this different from automated documentation tools?
faq.answer: Unlike JSDoc or Sphinx, this skill creates human-readable guides tailored to specific audiences and use cases.
